title: Newborn baby tragically dies in the arms of her mum's sleeping partner
text:

A one-month-old baby tragically died while sleeping in the arms of her mum’s partner, an inquest heard today.

Lyla-Rae Ayres was a "beautiful happy baby" in good health until the day before her death.

But her mum Shannon Maund told the one-month-old's inquest she had been crying and screaming an unusual amount in July last year.

Shannon put it down to having thrush in her mouth, Devon Live says.

The mother-of-two recalled changing Lyla-Rae's nappy and giving her a feed as normal before putting her back to sleep in her Moses basket at about 11.30pm.

She told how her partner Ben Price had agreed to get up with her in the night so she went to bed at about 12.30am, and was then awoken by him in the morning saying Lyla-Rae had stopped breathing.

(Image: Devon Live WS)

"Ben was sat up in bed with Lyla-Rae laying in his arms on her back. I could see her skin colour had changed and her eyes were closed," Shannon told Exeter County Hall.

In his statement, Ben said he was awoken by Lyla-Rae crying at between 3am to 3.40am on July 13, 2018, and took her out of her basket and gave her a feed.

He said: "She did not want to go back to sleep. She was wide awake so I put the TV on and put her on her back in the crook of my right arm.

"She was lying between my body and inside my right arm, and Shannon was to my right. She had not woken.

"I had not intended to sleep with Lyla-Rae in my bed."

When Ben then woke up a few hours later he said he saw she was unresponsive.

He said: “She was still in the same position and so was l, although her head had moved slightly. She felt cold and she was not breathing.”

Ben told how he carried out CPR after calling for an ambulance but she was later pronounced dead at North Devon District Hospital.

(Image: www.devonlive.com)

Recording an open conclusion, coroner Philip Spinney said: “It simply means the evidence does not fully explain how Lyla-Rae came about her death.”

Paying tribute to her after the inquest, Lyla-Rae's nanny Emma Ayres said: "She was a beautiful happy baby. She brought joy to all who knew her. I and the rest of the family miss her like crazy.

"Please be aware of the risks of co-sleeping, especially when you smoke as the risks are higher.

"We never thought something like this would happen to our family and the pain and anger of losing our beautiful angel will never go away. We will love you forever Lyla."

The inquest heard Shannon, Ben and his young son, lived in a three-bedroom terraced house in Bideford, Devon, with her mum and five siblings.

They slept on cushions from the sofa in the lounge with Ben’s son by them in a travel cot and Lyla-Rae in a Moses basket.

The inquest heard she met Ben on the internet while she was pregnant and he moved into her mum’s house in July 2018 with his son. They had been waiting for a private rental property to become available.

She told how, despite suffering with her own health during the pregnancy, Lyla-Rae was born healthy and was bottle fed and was doing well.

(Image: Lewis Clarke)

It was also heard how Shannon and Ben were both smokers, but did not smoke in the house, and had smoked a joint of cannabis the evening before her death.

A pediatric post mortem examination examination was carried out by Dr Andrew Bamber who concluded the cause of death was unascertained.

He told the inquest he could not rule out ‘risk factors’ such as accidental suffocation due to overlying, but there were plausible alternatives which could have contributed to her death.

He added there was evidence of a mild viral infection, but confirmed it would not have caused her death.

Dr Bamber said: “We are left with no definite reason why she passed away.”

When asked by the coroner how common it was for deaths in similar circumstances to be unascertained, he said: “In deaths of co-sleeping and sleeping in the same bed, somewhere in the region of 50 to 60 per cent won’t find a specific reason.

“It’s an area being actively researched in lots of different places.”

Police confirmed there were no suspicious circumstances surrounding her death and no evidence of neglect was found.
description: Lyla-Rae Ayres, described as a "beautiful happy baby", died at the home in Bideford, Devon
